ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: There was also an online lab.
Virtual lectures recorded for reference later
Live recorded (most of the time) lecture and online labs and office hours.
the live lectures were recorded.
virtual lab section as well
Zoom, virtual lab sessiosn

The lecture was a live lecture for about 2 times per week. During the lecture you have opportunities to ask questions or clarifications at the end or the middle when we take a break. Lectures are all recorded. Office hours were super helpful.
Live virtual lecture and virtual lab. Lectures were recorded.
Online labs
There was also a virtual lab component.
Watching recorded lectures were really helpful.
Virtual lab
Digital labs in Multisim
youtube videos, reading the textbook
Live virtual lecture and virtual lab.
live virtual lecture + live virtual lab section

There was also a virtual lab component. Students selected a time and date to attend a group, zoom lab section with a TA  where they could ask questions and obtain feedback and guidance. The lectures were recorded so I sometimes went back and re-watched them.
The lectures were also recorded, and there was a virtual lab that could be done on your own time.
Live virtual lectures and live virtual labs
Virtual labs
Live virtual lecture, but the lectures were recorded and posted and attendance was not mandatory
Lectures were also recorded.
Recorded virtual lecture and independent lab work.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Some basics of circuits
A lot about introductory electronics

I learned about the basics of electrical engineering including linear and nonlinear circuit elements, digital logic, transistors etc.  I gained the foundational knowledge to dive deeper into any of the topics on the syllabus.
I definitely expanded my knowledge of electronics and I feel a lot more comfortable with basic circuits, whether it be basic design or evaluiation.

A ton of really useful information and knowledge on the fundamental concepts in electrical engineering. I developed circuit analysis skills, which is valuable skill for any STEM major. I also learned a lot of new circuit devices, whether if it is linear or non-linear. There were a lot of interesting concepts too, for example that one class where we learned about over circuit or short circuit protection and the dangers of electrical shock, that was really interesting. Overall I strongly recommend this course, doesn't matter if you are majoring in electrical engineering or not, very useful.
I learned basic circuit analysis and gained some familiarity with using Multisim, a computer circuit simulation tool.

I learned a lot of insights on really how circuits work. Circuits had always been a tough idea to grasp in physics class, but the way it is taught in this class is very effective. Additionally, I learned about different elements used in circuits.
I learned basic electrical engineering concepts.
Basic knowledge of electronic circuits (resistors, transistors, capacitors, etc), technical writing
Insight to circuits
Basics of electrical engineering, now electrical devices and circuits work
learned a bit about intro to ee
I learned a lot about the process of writing formal lab reports and learned core electrical engineering concepts.
I learned a lot about how basic circuits work. It answered a lot of my questions about electricity and how it works.

I came in with very little background on the subject and learned a lot about circuit analysis. Topics from the node and loop method and Thevenin equivalents, to BJTs and MOSFETs were covered in the course. In addition to learning about circuit analysis, I also gained experience working with the virtual circuit simulation program called Multisim and learned how to complete a formal lab report in the context of the class. I feel like my problem-solving skills also improved.
I learned how to analyze circuits and how different circuit components worked.

We learned the basics of electronic circuits and circuit analysis including: Thevenin and Norton Equivalents, capacitors, inductors, and non-linear circuit elements such as diodes, transistors, MOSFETs, and a small introduction to digital logic. We also used a virtual circuit simulation program to carry out labs.

The fundamentals of electronic systems. Resistors, capacitors, inductors, diodes, transistors, transformers, MOSFETS, operational amplifiers, optoelectronics. Circuit analysis for all of the above. Practical experience with MultiSim and academic writing.
Circuit analysis, technical writing
Basics of AC and DC systems, various electrical components, different types of circuit analysis, and a very brief amount of digital logic.
Circuit analysis, complex analysis, frequency response, power optimization, nonlinear elements, basics of digital logic. Lab writing, electrical simulation software.
The course content as well as lab writing experience and feedback.
Simple circuits skills

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The lectures were a little unclear as a whole and some of the pset questions seemed disconnected from the lectures.
Teaching of concepts was sub-par, examples were not very helpful. You would let how to do that one example but couldn't do other problems.

Class slides were good. Office hours was very useful. Class was lenient and accommodating for covid difficulties. Homework and exams were marked quickly. Sometimes content in homework wasn't being covered until the class after it was due and I ended up using prior knowledge to know how to do the question instead. Class is also very confusing, not exactly sure how this could be improved though.
The strength of the course is its breadth. It provides good exposure to many complex topics and leaves room for wanting to know more.

Strengths: Helpful grading curve. If you have the right lab section, you will be able to learn a lot about how to approach the labs from your peers' questions.
Weaknesses: Lectures were very simple and didn't really cover much material. I didn't feel like I gained anything from going to lecture. The slides didn't really contain much information and only went over example problems (but only showed numbers and barely any explanations). I had to study/learn on my own, and the textbook wasn't too helpful either. Furthermore, the examples done in lecture were very simple compared to what was required in the psets and exams. The psets often covered topics not discussed in lecture or the textbook and were very hard to accomplish. The Labs were also very poorly written so that it was extremely hard to understand what you had to do. There were many spelling errors and incomplete sentences. Also, labs were not graded concurrently, so you couldn't learn from previous mistakes in each lab. Luckily the grading curve helped.

I think that overall the course was good, but something happened towards the end where we stopped learning a lot of new content and the Professor seemed a bit lost during the lectures. This, combined with often not making it through all of the slides, meaning that the homework often made little sense and even the TA's were surprised at our lack of knowledge.

Strength: I personally really like it when professors use power point presentations. There are many really great problems to apply the general knowledge we learn in class in the presentation slides, which I thought was really helpful. Professor Reed, the TAs, and peer tutors were definitely the stars of this course, they helped so much to clarify confusing concepts and answering questions. 

Weakness: I wish there were more practice problems available.

For people without any background knowledge of electronics, the lectures move through the material too quickly and are confusing. The lectures often skip multiple steps and make following along difficult. The virtual lab instructions were vague and difficult to understand. One strength of this course is that the peer tutors were fantastic and helped me understand the material and complete the homework assignments at their office hours. The course could be improved by revising the lab instructions to make them clearer and by revising the lecture powerpoints so that each step of a problem is clearly shown. Unfortunately, I didn't find this course very helpful for determining whether I want to continue to pursue EE, as I liked most of the material but was often frustrated by the course's format and pace and I didn't find the course engaging.

Strengths: interesting topics
Weaknesses: some of the explanations were a bit too fast
This course was well adapted to an online setting.

Strengths: This class was generally well-organized, had clear lectures, and it was not hard to get help or feedback.  Weaknesses: Some of the Zoom lectures really lacked quality, although most were good.  There was not a lot of student engagement during class.
Live lab wouldve been fun
Fun content, broad range covered - the transition from pure science to engineering coursework
lectures were not very clear, it was easier to learn by reading the textbook or watching other videos. Labs were good because it promoted hands-on learning which was helpful
Lectures were a little bland but this most likely was because of the online format.

I wish I couldve actually messed around with real circuits, but I understand the limitations of this semester. I do feel like I learned a ton of random theory and I really wanted to have more problems about using it to do something, but I might just have to wait more on that til later. Also, the labs take a ton of time, and I dont know how useful that time spent was in terms of helping me learn the material and how much of my grade it was worth.

Strengths: knowledgeable professor; interesting material; valuable, informative lectures; helpful and knowledgeable peer tutors
Weaknesses: homework based on Tuesday's lecture was due on Thursday so the peer tutoring could get crowded. It would be nice to have more peer tutoring or office hours between the time after class on Tuesday and before class on Thursday. 
The written lab directions were sometimes unclear.

Strengths: Professor Reed is really helpful. He does a good job explaining the material and is always willing to take questions during lecture or office hours. Also, the exams were graded pretty quickly, which I really appreciated.
Weaknesses: The powerpoint slides sometimes made it difficult to follow along during lecture, especially for example problems.
Sometimes the labs would be about topics that had not already been covered in class and would be confusing but other than a few hard-to-understand lectures, the class was taught very well.

Strengths: It's fairly cohesive. Problem sets seemed to line up well with the lecture content.

Weaknesses: Lectures were a bit hard to follow, especially later in the semester.

The labs were very effective in reinforcing material covered in lectures by allowing the student to engage with topics covered in class. The lab sections were very helpful in supporting lab work. The course could be made better by spending less time on advanced topics the student is not expected to know for the exam, such as complex power and transient response, and more time on complicated but important topics, particularly transistors and transistor amplifier circuits. In addition, lab instructions could be made clearer as some steps were not explained clearly and expectations about analysis were sometimes ambiguous.
This course is effectively structured.
The homeworks and the lectures did not always correlate in my eyes. The material did, but some of the questions had no comparisons to learn from.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Having all of the material online was very useful.
Examples being typed out on PowerPoints not helpful. Labs were pretty terrible because of the technical issues.
Accommodations put in place because of time zone difficulties were very useful.
The fact that lectures were synchronous was helpful in keeping some structure and the fact that they were recorded for later viewing provided some flexibility.

I think that the lectures and labs were overall pretty good, but the only part I would want to see improved was the lab instruction manuals. There was often a lot of ambiguity in what needed to be included in our final report, as well as what procedure to follow. For certain labs, this led to a dramatic increase in the intended/necessary time that they should have required. This was especially noticeable in lab three, the filters lab, where I spend almost 16 hours between trials and forming the lab report and got an 80 on it, losing points on a grade scale that was never given to us.
Maybe more opportunity to work with peers via breakout rooms? For example putting people in breakout rooms to solve an example question together.

The virtual peer tutoring office hours were successful. The live virtual lectures, however, were not engaging. Adding more information to the lecture slides would make it easier for students to follow along.
I liked how the class was live, but I wish that there were more office hours or an hour to do problems.
The virtual labs succeeded, although it would have been nice to be able to work on labs at any point in the day rather than having time slots.
I think the virtual labs worked fairly well, and I liked having synchronous Zoom lectures instead of recorded videos.  The office hours with peer tutors and Professor Reed were also very helpful.
Take home circuit kits for labs possibly

The digital labs still showed the principles of how circuits work
Lectures delivered live on zoom
Good usage of remote desktop access for labs. There is only one section for lecture so that sucked for people on different time zones, but it was good that they were recorded so we could watch later.
I think the practices were the best they could've been. While the class could've been a lot more engaging had it been in-person, I don't think there could've been a way to make it in person.

The lectures were very effective and I really appreciated that they were recorded. I also think the peer tutoring was a great resource. Having even more peer tutoring options near the due dates of assignments would be valuable since it can sometimes be more difficult to get help over zoom when the rooms are crowded (this is just due to the nature of zoom and the restrictions of the virtual environment; the peer tutors were great)

I feel like the course was run very well considering the circumstances. One thing that could be improved is using a partially filled out notes format rather than powerpoint slides. These could be filled out (particularly the examples) during the class on a tablet rather than using a powerpoint with all of the math already worked out.

More office hours between classes and PSET due dates would have been nice to have especially because we would learn a topic and have a few problems due on those topics 2 days later. The online lab worked well but longer/more frequent lab sessions would have helped a lot.

I was actually surprised at how well this class adapted. The lab component this semester was simulated, but it was not too difficult to get used to MultiSim and while sometimes the labs were not perfectly written I felt that they did a decent job of bridging between theory and practice nevertheless.
The virtual labs were very well adapted to the learning environment and allowed for student engagement effectively, which was very important for a virtual lecture course.
The lab sessions were not successful virtually. I feel like in-person labs would be exponentially better.
I thought the live lecture was a good idea.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Not unless they had to take it for their major.

No, I took this for fun hoping to learn aabout circuits but boy was I wrong. I got very little useful information out of this class. It was not fun, it was stressful and a ton of work with 10 page lab reports every other week in addition to PSETs. The textbook is horrendous and can't make up for lack of clear instruction during lecture. Don't take this class

If you want to be an electrical engineering major, then yes because you have to. If you are looking at taking this this because you want a STEM writing credit, bear in mind that this class is not easy. The writing part of this class (being the lab reports) is straight forward and pretty easy to do well with, however, the content of the class is very difficult and in my opinion, outways the benefit of being able to do a STEM writing credit
I would recommend this course to any student curious about technology and how things that you interact with on a daily basis  work (i.e. computers, electricity, LEDs).
No, only if its required of your major
I would. I think that overall it is a fair assessment of my engineering knowledge, the test content was very justified, and the professor seemed to care whether we knew the content or not.

Yes! Great intro class to electrical engineering, I learned a lot of new concepts that I wasn't really exposed to in high school. The professor is really great and patient when it comes to explaining confusing concepts. All of the material covered are also summarized concisely in the presentation, with step by step solutions to problems. I found that the textbook was a great supplement to the course, highly recommend purchasing a physical copy. The concepts can be a little challenging at first, but it gets SO much easier once you understand the concepts, because a lot of the analysis that is done is very logical and sequential. Once you get a grasp for the process, the analysis does get easier, for example, Professor Reed teaches you how to step by step solve for the Thevenin Equivalent first by zeroing the sources to find the Thevenin impedance, then you try to find the open circuit voltage etc. Plus you also just get a huge boost of self esteem and satisfaction when you solve a question right. 

My one tip for this class is go to the professor's office hours, go to TA office hours, go to peer tutor office hours. They are so helpful with explaining a lot of the new concepts. Don't be embarrassed to ask questions! Overall I strongly recommend this course, doesn't matter if you are majoring in electrical engineering or not, very useful.

If you're interested in EE or want to major in EE, you should take this course. However, if you're just looking for a science course (or a science course that carries a writing credit), I wouldn't recommend this course. The problem sets, even though they're confusing, don't take very long to do if you do them at peer tutoring. However, the five labs throughout the semester were time-consuming and each involved a >8 page lab report. The course isn't taught in an engaging way. In terms of grading, this course is fine, as the professor curves grades to students' advantage rather than on a true bell curve.
Yes, I would recommend this course because it gives a great understanding of circuits, which is an extremely important topic today.
I recommend this course if you are interested in electrical engineering. Taking this course is also a good way to figure out if you are interested in electrical engineering.

Yes, it's a great class to take if you're looking to gain a working knowledge of basic circuits.  I definitely feel a lot more comfortable in circuit analysis and can see the applications of this class in the real world.
Yes, if interested in EE
Yes, definitely for STEM students. Helps to understand the basics of analogue and digital tech, can probably read spec sheets after this course.
It's mandatory for some majors so you kinda have to take it, but no would not recommend.
Yes but only if they are pursing an EE related degree.
Yes, if they are interested in continuing with a lab science
Yeah, Id recommend it to anyone who wanted to know more about circuits. But i would warm them about the workload, especially the labs.
Yes, it was engaging and very informative. But students should be prepared to put in a good deal of work and be challenged.

I would recommend this course to another student. A lot of the skills you learn in this course can be helpful in many other areas. The circuits are basically puzzles, and solving them can help you practice approaching any problem in a different way. Also, the material is really interesting! It's cool to see how everything around you works.
I would recommend EE 200 to anyone who wants a solid foundation in electrical engineering or who want to just learn a bit about circuit analysis without investing too much time.

Yes, would recommend, although if you're a CS major like me looking for a deeper look into digital logic components you might be disappointed by the lack of digital systems content. Also, if you haven't taken a lab course with lots of writing yet, be prepared for that.
I would recommend this course to any student considering applied physics, engineering or computer science as it is a very effective and thorough introduction to electronics.
Yes, the course content was interesting and practical. The course was structured effectively and I enjoyed it. The professor was extremely knowledgeable and helpful.

I had to take it for my degree. I probably would recommend it because there's nobody better to learn from than Professor Reed. He's a titan in the field of electrical engineering, so I think there's a lot to be learned and understood from such a knowledgeable professor.
